text: The question my group wants to answer is: _________________________________
Here is a space for you to take notes. We have also suggested some of the variables for you. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or in the diagram tile.

• [initial number of cats]
  • [litter size]
  • [length of a cat pregnancy]
  • [ratio of female to male kittens per litter]
  • [age at which a cat is old enough to have kittens]
* Use the space below to consider how you would approach your first task.
<> First, drag the prompt from your task into this Workspace using the 6 dots in the corner of that tile.
<>Then use the prompt questions at left to help you organize your thoughts.
* You can use any of the tile types (diagram, text, drawing, image, table, graph) to help you with your task.
* Make sure you label your answers with the number of the question you are answering.
Here is a space for you to take notes. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or in the diagram tile.

• [initial number of cats]
  • [height of the building]
  • [area of town]
  • [etc.]
A diagram for specifying variable relationships, and a drawing tile for sketches are already made for you.
Drag the questions from this Activity on the left into this Workspace. Edit the text to write your answers below the questions.
Here is a space for you to take notes. Create variables using the variable tool on text tiles or drawing tiles, and develop your model in the diagram tile.

How many people in the world are talking on their cell phones as you read this question?

Analyze the initial model

  • What concerns do you have about the initial model?
  • Bold the concerns that you will try to fix in your revision.

{Write your answer here}

Assumptions and variables

What assumptions AND variables are you using in your model?

{Write your answer here}

Question 1

List at least 3 assumptions made to simplify the question about the students at South City High School:

  • {Type your assumption here}
  • {Type your assumption here}
  • {Type your assumption here}
Question 2 has three parts. Answer all three parts.

2A. Bold the name of the friend you were assigned to examine.

  • Friend Y
  • Friend Z

2B. How does that Friend's assumptions differ from the other Friend or from the initial solution?

{Write your answer here}

2C. How do those assumptions impact the Friend's final answer?

{Write your answer here}

Question 3

Use the [v=] button in the toolbar to create the variable chips that your assigned friend could use to build their model. Use the information on your handout to help you set the value for the variables.

  • {Create a variable chip here}
  • {Create a variable chip here}
  • {Create a variable chip here}

Question 4

Compare your variable chips with a partner. Find a variable for which the two friends did NOT agree on the value. In the space below, describe the variable AND why the friends did not assign it the same value.

  • {Describe the variable here}
  • {Explain why the friends set it to a different value here}

Exit Ticket

What is the purpose for making assumptions when solving a math modeling problem?

Question 1

Interpret and restate the client’s end goal in your own words.

{Write your answer here}

Questions 2

Describe what is important to consider as you do the first task, keeping the end goal in mind.

{Write your answer here}

Question 3

What assumptions will you make to help the client with the first task?

{Write your answer here}

Question 4

Use what is important and your assumptions to create variable chips for your client’s eventual model.

{Write your answer here}

Question 5

Describe how your variables are related to each other and/or to the client's end goal.

{Write your answer here}

Question 1

Write a few sentences telling the donor the volume of water needed for the tank and explain how you got your solution.

{Write your answer here}

Question 2

Recommend what size filtration system to buy. You can round your recommendation to 25 gallons.

{Write your answer here}

1. Write down at least two thoughts you have about this model. Your “thoughts” can be questions, ideas, or comments; they really can be anything but they must relate to a specific aspect of the model (e.g., one of the factors, the output, etc.)
**Build the food waste model(s) in the diagram tile below**
2. What does 0.35 represent in your own words?
4. Is the model’s output helpful? Why or why not?
Use your model (that is, adjust it, update it, change it...) to answer questions 6 - 8.

6. How much food does Clarkson University waste? Clarkson University in Potsdam, NY currently has 2852 undergraduate students, 2395 live on campus (i.e, they are residential) while 457 are non-residential students. According to the model, how much food waste does Clarkson generate per week? Adjust your model so that it shows your answer to this question.

  • In terms of the food waste law, what does the result you obtained mean for Clarkson University?
7. How many students can attend a university (either nonresidential or residential or a combination) before the school is in violation of the NYS Food Donation and Food Scraps Recycling law?

8. Using information from a university of your choice, determine how much food waste the school generates each week. Provide the following information/answer the following specific questions:

  • How many undergraduate students does your school have?

  • How many students are residential?

  • How many students are non-residential?

  • How (or where) did you obtain your information? (For example, you might provide a link to a website that you used.)

  • According to your model, how many pounds per week of food is wasted by your school?

  • Is the school you chose in violation of the food waste regulations? Why or why not?

  • Write down how you would share this information with an administrator from the school you investigated.

9. Should this model be updated? If so, identify three things that you would change (add, remove, or update) that you believe would make it better? If not, identify three reasons that this model should continue to be used by universities.

1. Which project will you improve? Bold the project that you will work on.

  • Time & Money
  • Food Waste

2. What concerns do you have about the initial model? Describe at least two below.

Which concern(s) will you try to fix in your revision? Bold it in your list above.

3. Document your improvement process.

What assumptions AND variables are you using in your revised model?

tiles.title: 4. Create a Drawing to Communicate Your Model

text: 5. Build your model in the diagram tile below.
6. Test your model in the diagram tile above and record the results in the next three tiles.

Test 1

2. What are your test results?

3. What do these results mean in the problem context?

7. Explain how your model compares with the initial model.
8. Explain how your model can be used to solve similar problems. Describe an example.

9. Write a report about your model by writing a letter to your client:

  • Stating how you have improved the initial model
  • Stating the strengths and weaknesses of your revised model
  • Advising your client and anyone on how to use the revised model

Dear Client,

Sincerely,

(Name of group members)
